items.title: Immune Microenvironment Signatures Predict Response and Survival in Rectal Cancer Patients After Neoadjuvant Chemoradiation
items.description: CONCLUSION: Immune-related gene expression patterns are associated with response to nCRT in rectal cancer. High expression levels of S100A8, SPINK5, ANXA1, FOXJ1, and CLEC7A were indicative of favorable treatment response, and S100A8 and SPINK5 were associated with prognosis. A machine learning-based model composed of immune-related genes showed strong predictive potential. Our results support the use of immune gene signatures to guide personalized therapy in rectal cancer.
items.conclusion: Immune-related gene expression patterns are associated with response to nCRT in rectal cancer. High expression levels of S100A8, SPINK5, ANXA1, FOXJ1, and CLEC7A were indicative of favorable treatment response, and S100A8 and SPINK5 were associated with prognosis

items.conclusion: We found that women with low SES were more vulnerable to the adverse effects of APO history, resulting in a greater increase in ASCVD risk.
